## 2. Theory

It is assumed that the reader of this paper already has basic knowledge of the mathematical principles of time series analysis. Therefore, this section will only briefly describe the mathematical models and processes

### 2.1. Time-Series

### 2.1.1. Stationarity

&nbsp;

\begin{equation}
  \label{eq:mean}
  E[x_{t}]=\mu
\end{equation}

\begin{equation}
  \label{eq:var}
  Var(x_{t})=\sigma_{x}^{2}
\end{equation}

\begin{equation}
  \label{eq:cov}
  Cov(x_{t}, x_{t-k})=R(k)
\end{equation}

### 2.2. Moving Average

**Identify trends, smooth out price fluctuations.**

#### 2.2.1. Equally-weighted Moving Average

&nbsp;

EqMA

\begin{equation}
  \label{eq:eqma}
  y_{t}=\frac{1}{L}\sum_{k=0}^{L-1}x_{t-k}
\end{equation}

#### 2.2.2. Exponentially-weighted Moving Average

&nbsp;

EMA

\begin{equation}
  \label{eq:ema}
  y_{t}=\frac{1}{\sum_{k=0}^{m}\alpha^{k}}\sum_{k=0}^{L-1}\alpha^{k}x_{t-k}
\end{equation}
